Key Takeaways 
At the end of the course, you should be able to:
• Identify where sentiment analysis can be applied
• Evaluate and analyze the classification techniques for sentiment classification and 
apply it with open-source libraries
• Design a sentiment analysis system for customer feedback and reviews
• Design a sentiment analysis system for news and social media for applications in 
finance
• Evaluate and assess sentiment analysis at a granular level for entities and aspects

Traditional Media vs New Media
• Traditional Media consists of print media, film studios, radios, 
newspapers, and televisions. Traditional media marketing 
often sends out messages to the customers instead of 
initiating conversations. The target audience of traditional 
media is a largely anonymous mass audience, and such 
marketing can be described as one-way communication
image
• New Media, delivered digitally, include various forms of 
media that are more interactive. Digital media marketing are 
usually conducted through social networking sites, internet 
advertisements, podcasts, vlogs, and blogs. The 
communication tends to be bidirectional in nature. E.g. 
companies posting product descriptions, customers posting 
product reviews, and company reacting to the reviews
Source: https://www.whackedout.in/blog/2019/08/09/how-digital-media-is-overtaking-traditional-media/ 
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

“Future of New Media” from Year 2009
image
Today’s social experience is disjointed because consumers 
have separate identities in each social network they visit. 
Internet identity is just the beginning of this transformation, 
in which the Web will evolve step by step from separate 
social sites into a shared social experience. Consumers will 
rely on their peers as they make online decisions, whether 
or not brands choose to participate. 
Socially connected consumers will strengthen communities 
and shift power away from brands and CRM systems; 
eventually this will result in empowered communities 
defining the next generation of products.
Source: https://www.forrester.com/blogs/09-04-27-the_future_of_the_social_web_in_five_eras/

Overview of Sentiment Analysis
image
• Sentiment analysis, also known as Sentiment Mining or 
Opinion Mining, is the field of study that analyzes 
people’s opinions, sentiments, appraisals, attitudes, and 
emotions toward entities and their attributes expressed 
in written text
• The entities can be products, services, organizations, 
individuals, events, issues, or topics. The field represents 
a large problem space
• Since existing research and applications of sentiment 
analysis have focused primarily on written text, it has 
been an active research field of Natural Language 
Processing (NLP)
Examples of Entities Annotated 
for Sentiment Analysis
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

Page_8:
image
image
Definition of an Opinion
Formally, an opinion is defined as a quintuple:
(ei, aij, sijkl, hk, tl), 
where 
ei is the name of an entity, 
aij is an aspect of ei, 
sijkl is the sentiment on aspect aij of entity ei, 
hk denotes the opinion holder, and 
tl is the time when the opinion is expressed by hk.
Furthermore, the sentiment sijkl can be positive, negative, or neutral, or expressed with 
different strength/intensity levels
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

2. Polarity Classification
• If a sentence in the phone review is classified as 
subjective, we will have to use some methods to 
determine its polarity
image
• One common method is to determine the sentiment 
associated with a particular sentence 
(i.e. sentence-level sentiment classification)
• This method is usually built on important assumptions 
such as:
1. A sentence expresses a single opinion 
2. A sentence is completed with punctuations such as “.” and “?”
3. A sentence captures the opinion within a clear context
Source: http://www.whatafuture.com/microsoft-using-sentiment-
analysis-software-to-predict-product-reviews/ 
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

3. Entity, Opinion Holder and Time Extraction
• In a collection of smartphone reviews, we have multiple entities 
mentioned by multiple opinion holders at different time
image
• For example, different users may express their opinions on 
different phone models based on different time of purchases. 
Some users may also change their opinions after using the 
phones for a while
• Furthermore, for each phone model, there can be multiple 
Source: https://www.splunk.com/en_us/blog/tips-
and-tricks/named-entity-recognition-and-
extraction.html 
aspects that the users can comment on 
• For example, users may review different aspects of the entity 
“Samsung Galaxy Fold3” such as screen size, battery ratings and 
OS version. The analysis of such review is also known as Aspect-
based Sentiment Analysis

image
image
Aspect-based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA)
image
• In Aspect-based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA), those aspects relating 
to an entity are extracted. Sentiments associated with these 
aspects are analyzed as they evolved over time
• Thus, ABSA can be seen as the process of building a 
comprehensive opinion summary at the aspect level, which 
provides useful fine-grained sentiment information for 
downstream applications (e.g. for Opinion Summarization)
• Some key tasks of ABSA includes extraction and categorization of 
entities and aspects (including entity and aspect resolution), 
sentiment classification and identification of opinion holders
Ref: Zhang, W., Li, X., Deng, Y., Bing, L., & Lam, W. (2022). A Survey on Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis: Tasks, Methods, and Challenges. arXiv preprint arXiv:2203.01054.
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

4. Opinion Summarization
image
• Opinion Summarization is an approach to aggregate 
and summarize the opinions from a large number of
users’ phone reviews
• Traditional text summarization typically involves 
selection and aggregation of important sentences 
(e.g. Extractive and Abstractive summarization)
image
• In contrast, opinion summarization aims to provide a 
quantitative summary of the sentiments regarding 
entities and their respective aspects in a systematic 
manner
• It is often used for Sentiment Visualization 
(More about this in subsequent slides)
Source: Liu, B. (2012). Sentiment analysis and opinion mining. Synthesis 
lectures on human language technologies, 5(1), 1-167.
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

5. Sarcasm Detection
image
• Sarcasm is a sophisticated form of speech act in 
which the opinion holder says something positive, 
one actually means something negative, and vice 
versa
• Sarcastic sentences are very difficult to deal with in 
sentiment analysis because common sense 
knowledge and discourse analysis are often required 
to recognize them
image
• While sarcastic sentences are not common in formal 
phone reviews, but they can be found quite 
frequently in the online discussions and user reviews
Link: https://aclanthology.org/C16-1231/ 
© National University of Singapore. All Rights Reserved.

Tweet Sarcasm Detection Using Deep Neural Network
Meishan Zhang, Yue Zhang, Guohong Fu

Abstract

Sarcasm detection has been modeled as a binary document classification task, with rich features being defined manually
over input documents. Traditional models employ discrete manual features to address the task, with much research effect
being devoted to the design of effective feature templates. We investigate the use of neural network for tweet sarcasm
detection, and compare the effects of the continuous automatic features with discrete manual features. In particular, we use
a bi-directional gated recurrent neural network to capture syntactic and semantic information over tweets locally, and a
pooling neural network to extract contextual features automatically from history tweets. Results show that neural features
give improved accuracies for sarcasm detection, with different error distributions compared with discrete manual features.

one actually means something negative, and vice 
versa
• Sarcastic sentences are very difficult to deal with in 
sentiment analysis because common sense 
knowledge and discourse analysis are often required 
to recognize them
Tweet Sarcasm Detection Using Deep Neural Network
Meishan Zhang, Yue Zhang, Guohong Fu

Abstract

Sarcasm detection has been modeled as a binary document classification task, with rich features being defined manually
over input documents. Traditional models employ discrete manual features to address the task, with much research effect
being devoted to the design of effective feature templates. We investigate the use of neural network for tweet sarcasm
detection, and compare the effects of the continuous automatic features with discrete manual features. In particular, we use
a bi-directional gated recurrent neural network to capture syntactic and semantic information over tweets locally, and a
pooling neural network to extract contextual features automatically from history tweets. Results show that neural features
give improved accuracies for sarcasm detection, with different error distributions compared with discrete manual features.

• While sarcastic sentences are not common in formal 
phone reviews, but they can be found quite 
frequently in the online discussions and user reviews
Link: https://aclanthology.org/C16-1231/

7. Opinion Search and Retrieval
• Frequently, we are interested to search and retrieve opinions about an 
image
entity or topic, similar to how we do Google or Bing searches. However, this 
turns out to be not so straightforward
• Similar to a general web search, an opinion search needs to perform two 
main tasks: 
1.
2.
Retrieve documents or sentences relevant to the user query
Rank the retrieved documents or sentences 
• However, opinion retrieval involves two subtasks:
1.
2.
Find documents or sentences that are relevant to the query
Determine whether they express opinions on the entity and/or entity 
aspect and whether those opinions are positive or negative
• Traditional web search engines rank web pages based on authority and 
relevance scores, but not based on sentiment scores. Thus, the top results 
do not capture the natural distribution of positive and negative sentiments 
of the whole population in a summarized form

• Opinions in reviews or social feeds are increasingly used by individuals 
and organizations to make decisions. Positive opinions often mean 
profit for businesses, and this provides strong incentives for imposters 
to post fake reviews to promote or to discredit target products or 
services.

of reviews

identities of reviewers

3 General Approaches to Sentiment Analysis
• Human crafted rules to identify subjectivity, polarity or 
the subject of an opinion
Rule Based
• NLP techniques include: Stemming, tokenization, part-of-
speech and parsing
• Lexicons (list of words and expressions)
• Systems rely on machine learning techniques to learn from 
data
ML-based
• Key steps involved are: pre-processing & feature 
generation, feature extraction, training and prediction
• Hybrid systems combine the desirable elements of rule-
based and ML-based techniques into one system. 
Hybrid
• One huge benefit of these systems is that results are often 
more accurate.

image

3 Levels of Sentiment Analysis
1. Message level: The aim is to classify the polarity of a whole opinionated message. For 
example, given a phone review, the system determines whether the review expresses an 
overall positive, negative, or neutral opinion about the phone. The assumption is that the 
entire message expresses only one opinion about the phone.
2. Sentence level: The aim is to determine the polarity of each sentence contained in a text 
message. The assumption is that each sentence, in a given message, denotes only one 
opinion about the phone.
3. Entity and aspect level: Performs a finer-grained analysis than message and sentence 
level. It is based on the idea that an opinion consists of a sentiment and a target (of 
opinion). For example, the sentence “The iPhone is very good, but they still need to work 
on battery life and security issues” evaluates three aspects: iPhone (positive), battery life 
(negative), and security (negative).

Analyzing Stock Market Movements Using Twitter Sentiment Analysis

Tushar Rao
NSIT, Delhi, India
Email: rao.tushar@nsitonline.in

Abstract—In this paper we i ite the complex relation-
ship between tweet board literature (like bullishness, volume,
agreement etc) with the financial market instruments (like

, trading volume and stock prices). We have analyzed
sentiments for more than 4 million tweets between June 2010
to July 2011 for DJIA, NASDAQ-100 and 13 other big cap
technological stocks. Our results show high correlation (upto
0.88 for returns) between stock prices and twitter sentiments.
Further, using Granger’s Causality Analysis, we have validated
that the movement of stock prices and indices are greatly
affected in the short term by Twitter discussions. Finally, we
have implemented Expert Model Mining System (EMMS) to
demonstrate that our forecasted returns give a high value of R-
square (0.952) with low Maximum Absolute Percentage Error
(MaxAPE) of 1.76% for Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA).

-Stock market ; sentiment analysis ; Twitter ;
microblogging ; social network analysis

Objective
Extract financial event analytics from textual data that can be combined with market &
trading data, to detect frauds especially illegal Insider Trading* in the derivatives market.
* Trading based on material nonpublic information.
« Added value for regulator (vs. rule-based system)
¥ Increase alerts precision (Currently false alerts are overwhelming)
Y Discover hidden suspicious trading patterns
¥ Provide organized contextual information for investigation

De-Dollarization and the Importance of Public
Sentiment in Cambodia

The challenge of promoting the use of the riel is not just one of monetary policy. It
also touches on questions of Cambodian national identity.

By Leang Seakleng

There are a number of reasons why the Cambodian
government has long sought to achieve “rielization” — limiting
the use of the United States dollar and promoting the
circulation of the local currency, the riel.

First, as Chea Serey, governor of the National Bank of
Cambodia (NBC), has put it, widespread use of the riel “could
enhance the effectiveness of conducting monetary policy to
maintain price stability and support economic growth.”

Second, the NBC cannot be a lender of last resort — offering
loans to banks or other eligible institutions that are Depositphotos
experiencing financial difficulties — if it cannot get people to

hold the local currency.

Is organic farming to blame for Sri
Lanka’s crisis?
